title: R46113
content: This report analyzes annual appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS) for FY2020, comparing enacted FY2019 appropriations, the Trump Administration's FY2020 budget request, and the enacted appropriations measures. It also provides additional informational resources on DHS appropriations and lists CRS policy experts for consultation. The suite of CRS reports on homeland security appropriations tracks legislative action and congressional issues related to DHS appropriations, focusing on discretionary funding amounts. The curr_chunk discusses specialized budgetary concepts related to appropriations legislation for the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). It explains terms such as budget authority, obligations, outlays, discretionary and mandatory spending, offsetting collections, allocations, and adjustments to discretionary spending caps. For a more detailed explanation, readers are referred to additional resources like CRS Report R42388 and the Government Accountability Office's Glossary of Terms Used in the Federal Budget Process. The curr_chunk provides details on the federal budget process for homeland security appropriations, using unrounded data for accuracy. It includes information on FY2019 appropriations from P.L. 116-6 and supplemental appropriations from P.L. 116-20 and P.L. 116-26. The curr_chunk discusses FY2020 appropriations for homeland security, including funding for natural disasters and security at the U.S.-Mexico border. Data is sourced from various congressional reports and the enacted levels from P.L. 116-93. The scoring methodology is consistent and developed with Congressional Budget Office (CBO) methodology. The curr_chunk provides an overview of the legislative process for FY2020 appropriations for the Department of Homeland Security, starting from the Administration's budget request to the enactment of annual appropriations in P.L. 116-93. The data is sourced from congressional reports and does not compare with OMB data due to scoring differences. The Trump Administration's FY2020 budget request for the Department of Homeland Security was delayed due to FY2019 appropriations. The request included $51.68 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, a 4.6% increase from FY2019. Additionally, discretionary funding was requested that does not count against spending limits set by the Budget Control Act. The Administration requested additional funding for FEMA and the Coast Guard in the FY2020 budget. The House Appropriations Committee marked up H.R. 3931, including $52.80 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, which was above the Administration's request and the enacted level for FY2019. The House committee bill included $14.08 billion in disaster relief-designated funding, reflecting the level in the Administration's modified request. The initial CBO scoring of the bill exceeded the subcommittee allocation by more than $3 billion, later revised to $1.9 billion. The Senate Appropriations Committee marked up S. 2582, including $53.18 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, $1.50 billion above the Administration's request. The Senate Appropriations Committee marked up S. 2582, including $53.18 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority, $1.50 billion above the Administration's request. The bill also included $17.35 billion of disaster relief-designated funding, $3.28 billion more than the Administration's modified request, and $190 million in OCO-designated funding for the Coast Guard. Congress passed a continuing resolution (CR) on September 27, 2019, temporarily extending funding at the FY2019 rate for operations. The continuing resolution (CR) (P.L. 116-59) temporarily extended funding at the FY2019 rate for operations through November 21, subsequently extended through December 20. P.L. 116-59 included provisions addressing DHS needs under a CR, such as special apportionment of funds for Secret Service expenses related to the FY2020 presidential campaign and accelerated apportionment for the Disaster Relief Fund. It also extended the authorization for the National Flood Insurance Program and allowed funds to be allocated for a planned restructuring of some DHS management activities. Section 101(6) extended immigration provisions linked to the appropriations cycle. On December 16, 2019, the House Rules Committee released text and explanatory statements for two consolidated appropriations bills. One bill, using H.R. 1158 as a legislative shell, included the FY2020 DHS annual appropriations measure with $50.47 billion in adjusted net discretionary budget authority. This was $1.22 billion below the Administration's request and $1.06 billion above the FY2019 enacted level. The bill also allocated $17.35 billion for FEMA in disaster relief funding and $190 million for the Coast Guard in Overseas Contingency Operations designated funding. The FY2020 DHS annual appropriations bill, signed into law as P.L. 116-93, allocated funding to the Coast Guard through Overseas Contingency Operations. Discretionary appropriations provide the majority of funding for DHS operations, with the remainder coming from fee revenues, trust funds, and mandatory spending. Annual appropriations for DHS are typically organized into five titles, with the first four focusing on thematic groupings of components and the fifth providing general direction to the department. When DHS was established in 2003, components of other agencies were brought together over a matter of months, with resources provided through existing account structures. In 2014, DHS began working on a new Common Appropriations Structure (CAS) to standardize appropriations format. Operating with over 70 different appropriations and programs has hindered transparency and decision-making. DHS implemented its first budget request in the CAS for FY2017, converting legacy appropriations structures to a four-category structure: Operations and Support, Procurement, Construction, and Improvements, Research and Development, and Federal Assistance. This new structure provides resources for operating expenses, asset deployment, technology development, and grant funding managed by DHS components. Some components of DHS have specific appropriations like Procurement, Construction, and Improvements (PC&I) and Research and Development (R&D). The Federal Protective Service and USCG's Retired Pay have unique funding mechanisms with a net-zero impact on total discretionary spending. The Guard's Retired Pay appropriation covers USCG retired personnel entitlements, including pensions, Survivor Benefits Plans, and medical care. It is categorized as appropriated mandatory spending and does not count against discretionary allocation. FEMA receives a separate appropriation for disaster relief activities authorized under the Stafford Act, allowing for consistent tracking of spending and transparency into fund availability. The National Flood Insurance Program is funded through a mix of mandatory and discretionary appropriations, with certain costs covered by fees collected by the government. Prior to FY2017, appropriations included specific conditions on how the budget could be spent. In FY2017, appropriations included specific conditions on how budget authority could be used. The federal government spending process involves budget authority enacted by Congress, funds obligated by agencies, and payments made to liquidate obligations. Budget authority is determined through appropriations acts or direct spending legislation, with the Antideficiency Act prohibiting agencies from obligating more funds than authorized. Congressional clients can consult CRS experts for guidance on DHS appropriations. Budget authority enacted by Congress can be indefinite in amount and available on a one-year, multiyear, or no-year basis. Obligations are incurred when federal agencies engage in transactions, creating a legal requirement for the government to pay. Outlays are the funds actually spent during the fiscal year. Multiyear and no-year budget authorities allow funds to be obligated for spending over a specified period or indefinitely. Budget authority enacted by Congress allows federal agencies to incur obligations and authorize payments from the Treasury. It consists of discretionary and mandatory spending, with discretionary funds appropriated yearly by Congress. The Budget Enforcement Act of 1990 defines discretionary appropriations as budget authority provided in annual appropriations acts, excluding entitlements. Mandatory spending, also known as direct spending, consists of budget authority provided in laws other than appropriations acts. Some mandatory entitlement programs must be appropriated each year. Within DHS, Coast Guard retirement pay is an example of appropriated mandatory spending. Offsetting Collections are funds collected by the federal government as part of a business-type transaction and are not considered federal revenue. They are counted as negative outlays. The DHS net discretionary budget authority is composed of discretionary spending minus any fee or fund collections that offset it. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts, funded by permanent or annual appropriations. The DHS budget includes mandatory entitlement programs like the Secret Service and Coast Guard retired pay accounts, funded by permanent or annual appropriations. Additionally, the DHS budget contains offsetting Trust and Public Enterprise Funds, which are not appropriated by Congress but are included in the President's budget to calculate the gross budget authority. The maximum budget authority for annual appropriations, including DHS, is determined through a two-stage congressional budget process involving 302(a) allocations. The 302(a) allocations are discretionary totals available to the Committees on Appropriations for annual appropriations bills. The appropriations committees then allocate the 302(a) discretionary funds among their subcommittees for each bill, known as the 302(b) allocations. These allocations must not exceed the 302(a) allocation to enforce budget discipline. Adjustments to the 302(b) allocations can be made during the year as appropriations bills progress. The 302(b) allocation for FY2020, based on the adjusted net discretionary budget authority, saw amendments in the House markup that exceeded the allocation by $3.066 billion, later revised to $1.9 billion. These provisions were not included in the final FY2020 DHS appropriations act. The Budget Control Act established enforceable discretionary limits for defense and nondefense spending from FY2012 through FY2021, with subsequent legislation amending these limits. The Budget Control Act established discretionary spending limits for defense and nondefense, with subsequent legislation amending the caps. Most of the DHS budget is nondefense spending, with allowances for adjustments for overseas contingency operations, emergency spending, disaster relief, and other specific purposes. The Office of Management and Budget determines the limit on disaster relief funding using a formula that includes a rolling average of spending over the last ten years. The Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 amended the formula to allow for a larger adjustment by adding 5% of emergency-designated funding for major disasters. OMB estimated a $17.5 billion adjustment for FY2020, the second-largest on record. The Office of Management and Budget estimated a $17.5 billion allowable adjustment for FY2020, the second-largest in history. This estimate includes the 10-year average, 5% of emergency-designated spending since 2012, and carryover from the previous year. The final adjustment for FY2020 may still vary from this estimate.
